results.description:
BUY TICKETS HERE

Hudson Grille’s massive patio now comes equipped with a heated tent and a great bar to help you get your drink on, while your 3 DJs keep you singing and dancing all night long. Don’t like what DJ 1 is playing? Don’t worry you’ll have two other DJ’s to choose from so you never have to stop partying.

DJ Green: Top 40’s and crowd favorites
DJ Red: 80’s, 90’s and 2k throwbacks
DJ Blue: Hip Hop and EDM

What the night includes:
Quiet Events Headphones
Glow in the Dark Gear
3 Live DJs battling for your attention

Dress Code:
No Boots
No bandannas
No Cameo Outfits (Unless its Themes with Event being Thrown)
No Hats

Special Notes:
Tickets are limited, so act fast!
This party is INDOORS.
Age Restriction: 21+

HOW IT WORKS
***Credit or debit card is necessary for the check-in process*** When you arrive you’ll receive a pair of special wireless headphones. You can adjust the volume and choose between up to three DJ with a flip of a switch. Each headset has a color LED that shows what you are listening to, so you can dance along with those listening to the same DJ as you. It’s super social; just lower the volume or take the headphones off and talk to that girl or guy. There’s no loud music that you have to talk over. Plus, there’s no ringing in your ears when you leave. At the end of the night, be sure to return your headphones as there will be a $100 charge to your credit or debit card if headphones don’t come back.
results.name: Quiet Clubbing Outdoors at Hudson Grille

results.description:
This groundbreaking, darkly comic horror film from director Joe Dante changed the look and feel of werewolf movies in ways light-years distant from Universal's horror classic The Wolf Man. The story begins with television reporter/anchor Karen White (Dee Wallace) taking part in a dangerous police operation intended to trap psychopath Eddie Quist (Robert Picardo). When confronted by Eddie face to face, she witnesses something horrifying enough to trigger selective amnesia. Plagued by a series of violent nightmares, Karen decides to admit herself to a posh recovery resort known only as "The Colony," run by her eccentric New Age therapist, Dr. Waggner (Patrick MacNee), and brings along her husband, Bill (Christopher Stone), for support. The night after they arrive, Karen and Bill are unnerved by eerie howling in the woods. Back in the city, Karen's co-workers Chris (Dennis Dugan) and Terry (Belinda Balaski) have been investigating Eddie's background after discovering that his body has disappeared from the morgue. Sifting through Eddie's possessions, they find a strange collection of artwork depicting wolf-like creatures, and decide to consult with Walter Paisley (Dick Miller, of course), the owner of an occult bookshop, on werewolf lore. Though he claims not to believe in the stuff he's selling, Paisley nevertheless convinces Chris to purchase a handful of silver bullets...just in case. Back at the colony, Dr. Waggner has organized a hunting party after hearing Karen's account of the nocturnal howling, but the men find nothing but a rabbit, which Bill is told to bring to the cabin of the sultry Marsha (Elisabeth Brooks) to prepare for dinner. After resisting Marsha's less-than-subtle sexual overtures, Bill is attacked by a wolf while returning to his cabin. The following moonlit night, the sleepless Bill wanders outside to find Marsha waiting and the two make love by the campfire, their bodies undergoing a frightening transformation. Just as Karen is beginning to suspect that her husband is hiding a secret far more threatening than marital infidelity, Chris and Terry have come to realize -- too late, in Terry's case -- that Eddie Quist is not only still alive, but not quite human...and he knows he's being followed. Chris arrives at the colony too late to save Terry, but manages to find Karen just as the colony's residents -- all of whom are werewolves, including Dr. Waggner -- are assembling to decide her fate. Dante fills his film with heartfelt homages to The Wolf Man and other classic horror movies, as well as a few clever visual puns and in-jokes from his tenure with Roger Corman, but never strays from the path to genuine horror, particularly when Rob Bottin's chilling monsters are onscreen.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iCmIr6OgtYg

group.name: Jersey City Road and Trail Running Meetup

results.description:
The courts at Crotona have finally been unlocked and are ready for our arrival!!!

I can't wait to see you all out there! :)

---- FAQ ---- 


What will we be doing at the Meetup? 
We will be meeting at the tennis courts for some friendly rallying, doubles, and singles play*. This meetup is open to players at any skill level; from beginner to advanced.

*For those of you who are interested in singles play, please keep in mind that the ability to play singles predicates on the amount of members who have RSVPed as well as court availability at the meetup event's venue. We cannot guarantee singles play in every instance.

How long will the meetup be? 
The time listed for the meetup event is when you can expect to the event host to be there. If you would like to arrive earlier or later than the start time listed, please leave a comment in the meetup event you plan to attend. This will give everyone in attendance a good representation of who is showing up at what time.

What will it be like? 
Our group is very friendly and loosely organized to allow for a fun experience.

Upon arrival, our event host will announce which court they are on in the comments of the meetup event. If you have a smartphone, we strongly suggest that you download the Meetup app for iPhone or Android to make communication easier.

When you arrive at the courts, look for the event host listed or other members of the group playing on (or near) the courts listed. Use the photos of each host/member on the website as a frame of reference.


Introduce yourself. Let the host know your level of play and you will be assigned to a court immediately.

Do members need to bring anything? 
All members must bring their own racquet. Unfortunately, we do not supply racquets.

All members are encouraged to bring a fresh can of new balls. You can always use a marker to mark your initials on your ball if you would like to keep them for future play. Please keep in mind that tennis balls only last a couple of days after taking them out of the can before they lose their bounce.

If you plan to donate to the group, you can leave your donation with the meetup event host or the head organizer, Frank, if he’s in attendance. All donations go towards the fees required to organize the meetup.

Who should come? Are newcomers welcome? 
Our meetup event is open to all players whether they're an absolute beginner or an advanced player. Players will be matched up with others based on their skill level. Beginners will be given an opportunity to play with higher level players so they can gain more experience with higher consistency.

It is a high priority for our group to help beginners increase their skill and become better players. If you are reading this and are an absolute beginner, please don't be intimidated. We want you to join us and have fun.

What should a newcomer expect? 
If you're new to the group, you'll learn very quickly that our community is extremely friendly. We have a colorful cast of characters from all walks of life who are ready and willing to have a good time.

Whether you're interested in easy-going rallying or competitive play, we can accommodate you.

Questions? 
If you have any other questions, concerns, or comments; please send them to our head organizer, Frank Tirado via email.
results.how_to_find_us: Check the comments section for our location
results.name: Saturday Morning Outdoor Tennis @ Crotona Park

results.description:
PLEASE BRING BOTH A BLUE T-SHIRT & A WHITE T-SHIRT.                                                                                                                                                                                           Downtown PickUp Soccer                                                                                                     

Started by a group of soccer fanatics who love to play the Beautiful Game and wanted to create a meetup for individuals of all levels. 

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown: 

1. Play safe,  games are 7v7 including goalie, NO slide tackles, excessive aggression will NOT be tolerated (the precinct is across the street...LOL!!). 

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

3. Pitch Location: Between Baxter & Mulberry St.with additional entrance on Worth & Bayard St. 

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street. 

5. HAVE FUN!

See you Downtown! 

Terms and Conditions of the participating in our group:

PLEASE READ THESE TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF USE CAREFULLY. 
BY USING THIS WEBSITE, YOU AGREE TO THESE TERMS AND CONDITIONS. 

JOINING AND SIGNING UP FOR DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT: 

I certify that I am 18 years of age or older and that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in DOWNTOWN PICKUP SOCCER activities. results.description:
Join us at 8am for a run to Hoboken Pier A and back.
http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/121375029

Yes, there is a waterfront route to Hoboken. Enjoy the fun of cruising around Hoboken Pier A; around the new park and children playground at Newport where you will feel if you are at the beach. Get inspired by the man made majestic views of Manhattan!

The mapped distance is approx. 5.88 miles. You may run less or more in that time. We turn back after running 30 min to be back at 9 am. Hyatt pier is .31 miles so a double loop gets some runners 6.5 miles on this run.

9 am we run to Liberty State Park, a favorite place to run for most of us. Run on!

results.description:
This meetup is for both hikers and runners. Here is the plan:

We'll go up and down the Bear Mountain following the Appalachian Trail. If you're coming to hike (or if you're not familiar with the AT trail), then you can stick with me and other hikers. If you want to go faster, then run ahead and just follow very well-marked AT trail and run up and down the mountain more than once. There is also nice running path around the pond. If you wish, you can also enjoy the Bear Mountain park in any other way you want, but everyone should be back to the parking lot by 1pm.

We just had a similar event last weekend, you can check out the photos here: http://www.meetup.com/RAWTRAIL/events/229450322/


COURSE: Terrain there is challenging (rocks, roots, mud, etc), so be prepared. Combined elevation gain - over 1200ft per loop (around 6 miles).


Here is a map of all trails in the area, have it with you just in case: http://nysparks.com/parks/attachments/BearMountainTrailMap.pdf

NYC PICK UP: To reserve a ride just RSVP to this meetup. The location of pick up is next to the bus station by GW Bridge (please get there by 8 am sharp!). To get there you can take A train (to 175th street). We will be waiting in our huge black RawMobile at the corner of 178th street and Fort Washington Avenue (next to the fruit stand). My phone number is[masked]O-7784 just in case.


The drive takes less than one hour, we'll be back in NYC around 2pm.


The price to RSVP will go up as more people sign up (to reward those who register early).

If you don't need a ride from NYC, then just come over to the Bear Mountain and meet us there (see the map at the bottom of this post). If you're coming on your own, then remember to bring some cash as they are charging $8 (soon to be $10) for parking at the Bear Mountain.

Cell reception: T-mobile doesn't work well there, AT&T is a bit better. Please ask questions in advance and try to be on time.

Bathrooms: There are nice bathrooms right by our starting point on the parking lot.

Attire: I would recommend trail running shoes. Bring wind-proof jacket, it’s a bit colder there than in the NYC area. Also, be ready for some mud. Feel free to bring a set of dry clothes to change (in the bathroom) after the hike. You can leave extra stuff in the car while we run.


Water/Food: We will have complementary bottles of water and some fruit for everyone. Feel free to bring your own snacks/drinks as well.


Weather: We will cancel if it is expected to rain heavily, please check this page a day before the trip (I would also send cancellation notice in that case)


Any questions - send me a meetup message. Just in case, my cell is[masked]O-7784.

Please note that this is not a guided tour and by signing up you are agreeing to the following terms:
Legal Disclaimer

results.description:
Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
This is an advance level loop hike of 8 miles which begins climbing Breakneck Ridge then to Sugarloaf Mountain and return to the parking area. Expect a steep rock scramble climb up Breakneck Ridge with rewarding, spectacular 360 degree views from several points of the Hudson River and Storm King Mountain.

Weather: Light rain okay. Heavy rain cancels. Check this site for updates. 

Equipment: Sturdy hiking shoes. Appropriate weather gear. Water (at least 2 liters). Snacks/lunch & hiking poles (if needed). Camera. Good conversation. Positive and environmentally friendly attitude. Leaders cell # emailed to those who first email their number.

RISK DISCLAIMER:Please remember this is a social event and not a professionally guided hike.  By participating in this hike, you are agreeing not to hold anybody responsible for injuries or accidents, and you acknowledge hiking is a dangerous activity that could lead to injury or death. Always come prepared and equipped as if you are hiking on your own.  In the event of an emergency, your fellow hikers will do their best for you, but there is no guarantee any of the participants will have medical or rescue training.

By participating in this event you also acknowledge that you understand the level of difficulty and are physically capable, properly attired and have the necessary gear and supplies required for participation in this activity.

The following information is taken from the NY/NJ Trail Conference.


Driving Directions

Take the Palisades Interstate Parkway to its northern terminus at the Bear Mountain Bridge. Cross the bridge and proceed north on Route 9D for about 8.5 miles to the Village of Cold Spring. Continue ahead on Route 9D for another two miles (beyond the intersection with Route 301in Cold Spring) and pass through a tunnel under Breakneck Ridge. Proceed for another 0.3 mile and park in a small parking area on the right (east) side of the road, just before a small blue "adopt a highway" sign.
Train
Take the Metro-North Hudson Line to the Cold Spring station and walk north on Route 9D to the trailhead. On weekends and holidays, two trains in the morning stop at the Breakneck Ridge station, a short distance north of the trailhead. Find link for info here

.
results.name: Breakneck Ridge and Sugarloaf Hike (Cold Spring, NY)

PS2G - Local Game. Global Change.

Started by a group of soccer fanatics who love to play the Beautiful Game and wanted to create a meetup for individuals of all levels. 

Our Mission: Play safe, get your workout on & HAVE FUN!!

The Lowdown:

2. Cleats are permitted, and Sneakers or Turf Shoes are acceptable as well. We play for an hour with a break in the middle. If no volunteered goal keeper, players will rotate the position. We play with corner kicks and throw-ins. Also, everyone should bring a Blue T-Shirt AND a White T-Shirt.

3. Pitch Location: Between Baxter & Mulberry St.with additional entrance on Worth & Bayard St. 

4. Nearest train stations: Brooklyn Bridge (4, 5 & 6), Canal Street (A, B, C, Q, R, N & 6), Chambers Street (J and Z). Citibike station is available right next to the field on Worth Street.

results.description:
For this Healthy Neighborhoods Mobile Market volunteer effort in Harlem, please register through the City Harvest website at the link below (your RSVP will be added in the HarlemGo Meetup manually after doing so).


https://cityharvestvolunteers.civicore.com/index.php?section=indGpRegistrations&action=profile_conditional&fwID=4405


The Registration process is as follows:


• Follow the Group Sign-up Link above and click "New User" to create a new volunteer profile and click "Submit" (repeat or previously registered volunteers can simply log in)

• Read project details and click "Register" to confirm participation

• You will then receive a confirmation email and a reminder the day before the project


Only 10 volunteers are needed. All volunteers must be 18 years and older.

Description of Duties:

Volunteers will be stationed at 3-4 market tables, each supplied with thousands of pounds of fresh produce that they will help distribute to eligible market-goers. Sample produce items may include bananas, onions, cabbage, or potatoes. As the market-goers stop by each table, volunteers greet them-and then weigh and bag the produce. Note: All food is distributed free of charge and the volunteer effort WILL BE indoors in the event of cold temperatures / bad weather.


That's it for now. If you have any questions, feel free to give me (Daniel) a call or text at [masked]. Thanks!

About City Harvest Healthy Neighborhoods Program


Nearly 1.4 million New Yorkers are facing hunger and for many people that City Harvest serves, healthy food is unavailable and unaffordable. In turn, diseases related to poor nutrition – including diabetes and heart disease – tend to be concentrated where demand for emergency food is greatest.

As a natural extension of the anti-hunger work we began more than 30 years ago, City Harvest developed Healthy Neighborhoods programs to respond to the need for emergency food, improve access to fruits and vegetables for residents in low-income communities and provide nutrition education that will inspire affordable, healthy meal choices. Through our Healthy Neighborhoods programs, City Harvest partners with residents, community organizations, afterschool programs, and local businesses. Together we work to achieve a long-term impact in the fight against hunger by engaging residents in healthy choices and enhancing the local food landscape. Building off our nutrition education classes which began in 2000, and our Mobile Markets which began in 2004, City Harvest has since expanded Healthy Neighborhoods programs to high-need communities across the five boroughs.

results.description:
https://goo.gl/maps/mQir286nVdn


Windham to Blackhead Traverse - SPRING REQUIRED
------------------------------------------------------------------
11.3 Miles / 3700' Elevation Gain
Two bail-out options at 6.7 miles and 9.7 miles RT.
------------------------------------------------------------------

Make some room for Easter dinner!

Several Big Views Throughout Hike!


Time and Pace:

Meetup Time: 9am


Pace: 1.3 MPH Overall Minimum
Done By 6PM.


Easy Pace, but hike is a little longer.
End early if you want to.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Notes:

We will be meeting at the ending location (Big Hollow TH) in order to leave most vehicles there.  (All bailout options lead to ending location.)  (Big Hollow TH is at the end of the road.)  Stronger hikers will be asked to transport people to the starting location (Elm Ridge TH), a DEC parking lot at the end of Peak Road. 


This is traverse, so the hike will not end in the same place it starts, so be early and ready to hop back in the cars at the appointed hour.


Early Spring Conditions:  There are no leaves...Beware the sun.  Mud probable.  Please try to stay on trail.


Bail-Out Note:  I don't mind if you only want to do Windham, I only ask that you  do Not disappear on us.  If you want to bail and you can't relay the message to the group, you must wait at the trailhead, or have a prearranged way to leave us a note, in order to let the group know that you made it back to your vehicle.


------------------------------------------------------------------
Planned Route:

We will be taking the Elm Ridge Trail (Yellow Blazed) to it's termination on the Escarpment Trail (0.9 miles / 350').  Near the intersection is the Elm Ridge Leanto (w/ privy), so the trail might become confused...  We are hanging a right, up the slope, to the East.  Follow Blue Blazes and signs for Windham.  After 2.2 miles / 1200', you will top-out on Windham.  Another 2.8 miles / 300' of mostly downhill will get you to the intersection with the Black Dome trail.  If you've had enough at this point you can bail out by hanging a right, going South, follow Red Blazes and signs for Big Hollow Rd.  If you are continuing on, go straight, stay on the Blue Blazes, follow signs for "Black Head Mt".  After 2.37 miles / 600' will be the intersection with the Batavia Kill Trail.  You can bail here by turning right and continuing North-West, follow Red Blazes, and signs for Big Hollow Rd.  Otherwise, continue on the Escarpment Trail and Blue Blazes to Black Head Mountain (0.9 miles / 1120'). *Done with Elevation Gain*  The Blackhead Summit is a trail intersection.  We will be turning right, on the Blackhead Mountain Trail, follow signs for BlackDome, on White? NotBlue Blazes.  At the bottom of the col (after 0.6 miles), we'll be turning right, onto the Black Dome Trail (Red Blazed).  1.9 more miles will get you to the cars.  Follow signs for Big Hollow Rd.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Additional Notes:

As always, GPS with the points below, maps, and tracks is recommended, and map/compass/headlamp required.

Bring more than enough cloths, food and water.


Please do not show up without an RSVP or contacting a host.

------------------------------------------------------------------
Navigation:


Unless you are familiar with the area, if you have a GPS, please load these items:

• Big Hollow Trailhead (Meeting/Ending):[masked], [masked]

• Elm Ridge Trailhead (Starting):[masked], [masked]

• Elm Ridge / Escarpment Intersection:[masked], [masked]

• Windham High Peak:[masked], [masked]

• Escarpment / BlackDome Intersection (Bail-Out #1):[masked], [masked]

• Escarpment / Batavia Intersection (Bail-Out #2):[masked], [masked]

• Blackhead Mountain:[masked], [masked]

• BlackHead Mt / BlackDome Intersection:[masked], [masked]

------------------------------------------------------------------
Waivers and Stuff:


If you join this event you are responsible for yourself in all regards; including but not limited to the following.  You must be prepared to navigate yourself to your objectives and back to your vehicle.  Which means being familiar with the route prior to arrival, and bringing whatever navigation aids necessary.  You must know the mileage / elevation gain / terrain / planned pace, and be familiar with your ability to traverse them, and what gear is recommended for yourself given the conditions.  Unless the meetup is labeled as "Beginner", it is your responsibility to gauge your ability to keep up with the group and get to the vehicles within a time-frame as to not cause alarm; this may mean that you may not meet all of your objectives.  Your first objective is always to get back to the vehicles safely, and let the rest of the group get on with their trip, so keep track of the time, turn around if you need to, and try to let people know if you think you might disappear.  There will be no gear-check, but extra food, extra water, rain layers, headlamp, lighter, compass, and whistle, should be things that you are very rarely without.  Most people are unfamiliar with how quickly rain on a previously 90 degree day can become a survival situation, so it warrants saying that, if there is any chance of rain, you need raingear.

------------------------------------------------------------------

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.

Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.

Приглашаю на маршрут с многочисленными обзорными точками.

С высоты Bearfort Ridge посмотрим на New Jersey

Недалеко от NYC.

Маршрут для нас новый.

---------------------------------------------------

Lets hike Bearfort ridge

The Meeting Point

[masked], [masked]

The parking near the Greenwood Lake Marina!!!!

Парковка В ЛЕСУ около Greenwood Lake Marina!!!!!

Directions:

To park for this hike travel on Route 17A from Warwick to Greenwood Lake. At the bottom of the hill stay right on Route 210 through the village of Greenwood Lake. Route 210 travels along the west shore of the lake and heads toward New Jersey. Watch for a sign that says "Welcome to New Milford Township". Just before the sign turn up the driveway to the trailhead parking.

-------------------------------

Take I-287 to Exit 57 and continue on Skyline Drive to its western end at Greenwood Lake Turnpike (County Route 511) in Ringwood. Turn right and proceed for 8.2 miles to an intersection with Lakeside Road. Turn right and follow Lakeside Road (still designated County Route 511) for 2.4 miles to the Greenwood Lake Marina, just south of the New Jersey-New York boundary. Turn left and park on the left side of the dirt access road, west of Lakeside Road. Do not, under any circumstances, park on the private property of the Greenwood Lake Marina, on the east side of Lakeside Road.

-------------------------------------------------------

Start Point

[masked],[masked]

</a>

The trail head is located on Clinton Road in West Milford. Take NJ Route 23 North, through Newfoundland and exit right onto Clinton Road. Go north approximately 6 1/2 miles. Parking will be on the left. A large green sign that says "Wildcat Mountain Wilderness Site-Project U.S.E." is adjacent to the parking area. Alternatively, you can take NJ County Route 511 North (Greenwood Lake Tpk.) to Greenwood Lake. At the traffic light where 511 turns right onto Lakeside Road continue straight ahead onto Warwick Tpk. Follow Warwick Tpk. approximately 2.5 miles to the intersection with Clinton Road. (Lake Wakover will be on your left) Turn left onto Clinton Road and travel south approximately 1.7 miles. The parking area will be on your right.

<a href="http://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/docs/Wawayanda%20State%20Park%20no%20bleed%202.pdf">http://www.state.nj.us/dep/parksandforests/parks/docs/Wawayanda%20State%20Park%20no%20bleed%202.pdf

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
We've done a bunch of rides up through western CT to Housatonic State Forest, typically starting in New Milford and traveling on a bunch of mild dirt roads up north. The best riding of the trip is in Housatonic forest, but by the time we get up there it's usually later in the day and we are a bit tired from the morning's ride up. 

For this ride I'd like to focus the whole trip on Housatonic Forest. The forest has a main loop that is fairly loose gravel two track, with tons of tighter, more technical trails that jut off. Let's spend the day exploring these trails and everything the forest has to offer. 

We can plan to either meet up somewhere farther south (like Max BMW) and ride up as a group or we can meet at the gas station listed as the current meet up location, which is about 10 - 15 minutes away from the entrance to the forest. 

This is an intermediate level ride. You want at least 70/30 street/dirt tires for this trip but knobbies are best (I shouldn't talk I'm running the shitty stock tires on my KLR).

results.description:
Please join us for a Catskills bushwhack. Groups are limited to 15 on Catskills bushwhacks. People I have hiked with before and whose hiking level I know will have preference but we welcome all.


Distance: Approx. 9.5 miles

Difficulty: Strenuous

Duration: Approx. 6 hours

Trail Map: NY NJ Trails Conference map #142

Weather: Rain cancels but will make the call by midnight the night before

Parking

Take Claryville Rd. north from Rt. 55 in Curry outside of Grahamsville. Just short of Claryville turn left onto the Frost Valley Rd. Pass the Frost Valley YMCA camp and look for the parking area after a little more than a mile on the right. You can also come in from Rt. 28 at Big Indian. N[masked] W[masked]

The Hike

From the parking area we cross the road and walk away from Frost Valley to find the blue-blazed Pine Hill-West Branch trail. After 2 miles there is a lean-to on a short path to the left. A short distance after the lean-to before we cross a tributary of Biscuit Brook we will start bushwhacking up Fir Mountain. We will come down on the trail after summiting Big Indian rather than attempting a bushwhack descent when we are tired at the end of the hike.

Directionally bushwhack ascents are easier as the right direction is up. Once we summit Fir and sign in at the canister the more directional challenge begins. There is not much up and down between Fir and Big Indian but we need to be sure we hit the col at the Catskill Divide. Walking too far down will require us to hike even further back up so hitting that col is important. Your google maps offline download of Fir will help in identifying that col. After nailing that col we will continue west to hit Big Indian. Total distance between Fir and Big Indian is about 1.5 slow miles.

Big Indian’s peak is about 0.25 miles away from the trail (there is a canister) so even if we don’t hit it exactly, we will hit the trail and use that as our guide to the peak (there is a pretty obvious herd path to it).

From here it is about 2.5 miles going down to the lean-to we saw going up and we will be well on our way to having bagged two more Catskill peaks.

Things to Do - PLEASE do this. It will GREATLY reduce your chance of getting lost.

GPS or smart phone apps

- Google maps – pin starting point and shows peaks – DOWNLOAD AN OFFLINE MAP OF FIR MTN – open google maps, in the search line put Fir mountain, Shandanken, NY, at the bottom white ribbon tap on the name of the mountain, hit the download button. There you have it. When you go to the main screen, the top white ribbon (top left) will have three horizontal bars. Tap and you will see fir mountain as one of your offline areas.

- MyTracks (free) or MapMyHike (free) or some other tracking app

Map http://www.gpsies.com/map.do?fileId=wldpntbotoqmgvxj

Navigate to the above website on your phone. Go to the bottom and download the GPX version. Press on “open” top left and you can save it to MyTracks (free download) which is a great free nav tool. It will show you were you are and will show you the path that was followed by the person who created the download.

- (Optional) NOT FREE – PDF Maps – you can buy the NY-NY Trails map of the entire Catskills for $17 and get the same functionality you would with the TIP at the top with MyTracks.

Things to bring

GPS or Smart phone

Long pants and long sleeve shirt or willingness to get a little scratched up

Eye protection – goggles, glasses, etc.

Whistle – carries further than voices

Battery in case your phone runs out of juice

2 liters of water/fluid

Something to eat to replenish the energy pushing through brush will take out of you

Dogs: Not allowed

Guests: No guests for this hike. All hikers must be members of WHMG.

Important: Be certain to check this webpage and your email prior to the hike for any last-minute changes or cancellations.

Important notes about WHMG hikes:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TKFHHQIDkgNVWs-4XmPVJM3qXp7X9B6jIrUZSWgyECU/edit

Liability Waiver: Hiking or outdoor activities have inherent risks. Your participation in our hikes or other events could be dangerous and can result in serious injury, medical emergency, even death. You agree to participate in this event completely at your own risk and to take full responsibility for your own safety and well being, including those of your guests.

results.description:
Come join us for some challenging Rock Scrambling and Crevice Exploration at Mohonk Preserve and put your Rock Scrambling skills to the test! This is no average walk in the park!  You will get a full body workout while exploring the many crevices at Rock Rift and the towering rock walls and breakdown at Bonticou Crag.


WE WILL MEET AT THE SPRINGFARM TRAILHEAD @ MOHONK PRESERVE

Upper 27 Knolls Rd

High Falls, NY 12440

[masked], [masked]

http://www.mohonkpreserve.org/spring-farm-trailhead


1) WE WILL START OUR DAY AT THE LESS VISITED ROCK RIFT TRAIL

Our adventure at Rock Rift: We will hike about 2-3 miles of carriage road  to arrive at the less visited Rock Rift Trail for some warm-up crevice exploration. This section is marked by red arrows and is fun to explore without requiring any real advanced skills. 


2) OUR SECOND STOP WILL BE AT BONTICOU CRAG

Our adventure at Bonticou Crag: From Rock Rift we will hike approximately 2-3 miles of carriage road to Bonticou.  Bonticou Crag is like a giant playground of scrambles and climbs surrounded by beautiful views of the adjacent Catskills.  Bonticou also offers some small Talus caves beneath its breakdown for the more adventurous! (You might consider bringing some knee-pads, a helmet and a headlamp if you want to explore these.)  If you've ever been to Bonticou before you probably only touched the surface.  We will fully explore the area taking "trails" up and down the cliff face on the left, right and middle as well as scrambling through its breakdown for the entire length of the outcropping.


TOTAL DISTANCE: Approximately 8-10 miles

SCRAMBLING PACE: Slow but physically challenging (not to be confused with easy)

ESTIMATED HIKE/SCRAMBLE TIME: 7+ hours

DIFFICULTY: Intermediate - Rocky Terrain & Crevices with possible loose, slippery or jagged rocks. Must have a good sense of balance and not have an unnatural fear of heights

CURRENT WEATHER FORECAST:  Partly Sunny with a high of 52 degrees.

FEE: Please Note Mohonk Preserve charges a $12. fee for day use.  Season Passes are also available for $55. or $45. for students.  If you enjoy Mohonk preserve you can apply your $12. day usage fee towards the purchase of a membership by simply saving and submitting your bracelet (pass) within 2 weeks of purchase at the Visitor Center.


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Raincoat/Windbreaker and proper layering for 40-50 degree weather

• "Scrambling" Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• Headlamp with spare batteries - Home Depot has a great 100 lumen headlamp for only $12.99!

• A Small Pack - nothing too large that will become a hindrance in the scrambles

• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.


OPTIONAL GEAR:

• Climbing Helmet (Bicycle helmet will do) Not mandatory but rocks could get kicked loose (especially recommended if you are clumsy or want to check out the Talus caves at Bonticou)


RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set


AFTER THE HIKE FEEL FREE TO JOIN US FOR SOME FOOD AND DRINKS AT THE

MAIN COURSE MARKETPLACE

175 Main Street
New Paltz, NY 12561

[masked]

http://www.maincoursecatering.com/marketplace.html

Monday: Closed
Tues - Thurs: 11am - 9pm
Friday: 11am - 10pm
Saturday: 11am - 9pm
Sunday: 9am - 9pm

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Making Every Moment Count – A Day Retreat of Death Awareness 

with Kadam Peter

Despite the inevitability of our death and the complete uncertainty of its time or manner, few of us give it a moment’s thought until it is too late.

In this retreat, we can learn how coming to terms with our mortality enriches our life and enables us to meet our passing with dignity, confidence, and joy.  We can be inspired to live a pure, liberating lifestyle in which every moment is meaningful.

Schedule

10:00-11:30 Introduction

11:45 – 12:30 retreat session one

2:00 – 2:45 retreat session two

3:15 – 4:00 retreat session three

Kadam Peter Kurczynski is the resident teacher of Dharmachakra Buddhist Center.<a href="http://meditatenj.org/newsite/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/Resident-Teacher__Peter_Kurczynski.jpg"></a>

He has been practicing Buddhism in formal study programs of the New Kadampa Tradition for nearly twenty years. His teachings are timely, practical and easy to apply in everyday life.  In 2013, he received the title “Kadam,” meaning senior lay resident teacher.  Kadm Peter has participated in numerous meditation retreats, and regularly attends international festivals of Kadampa Buddhism

$25 for all day retreat

results.description:
**INDOOR, FUTSAL OR SNEAKERS**  

                               NO CLEATS or PLASTIC STUDS!

         NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED PICKUP SOCCER GAMES 

                                      @ RIVERSIDE Park!

                             See our page on Facebook!:

                        ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQxq4zYJDFg

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

We'll play 3 simultaneous games of 8 on 8, with goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

No power shots allowed. No power shots means; you can shoot the ball but not as hard as you can. This doesn't mean that you can not take the shot at all. Kicking the ball or taking the shot on the goal, is of course allowed.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

Riverside Park at West 108rd Street

Take the 1 RED Line Train to Cathedral Pkwy an walk two blocks down, to 108th Street and Riverside Dr.

The field is down the lower level near the river. You can easly access the field from 108th Street. Remember, the field is not visable from the street level, you have to walk down the stairs from Riverside Dr & 108th Street. and you will see the newly renovated fanced-in soccer field next to the river.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.


What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.50 when you RSVP. This $9.50 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to a local bar for brunch and a Pint or Two.

                                        Lion’s Head Tavern


                                     995 Amsterdam Ave

                                      New York, NY 10025

                                           (212)[masked]

Meetup/Hangout – 9:45 am

Whole Foods (Union Square) -- upstairs cafe. Show up a bit early to say hi, chat, and drop off any thing you don’t want to run with: jackets, bags, phones, etc. Somebody will always stay to watch the stuff.

Run – 10:00 am

Run 1 mile, 3 miles, 5 miles, or whatever you want. We'll head to the West Side Highway together. No pressure and no limits. Totally informal. Lots of different paces for lots of different people. Even walking speed is encouraged!

Brunch – 10:45 am

Whole Foods has ALL THE FOOD. Come get some.

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It’s that easy. First we run, then we eat!

由北大和复旦校友创办于2015年4月，坐落于纽约华尔街，是美国东部首家专业华人创业孵化器。 蜂巢聚创提供创业咨询、孵化、投资及创业社交平台服务。其优势在于拥有一支具有中美初创企业实战经验的专家级执行团队及配套天使基金和一个深耕于美东的前沿人才和科研网絡。可提供风险管理、法律事务、人力资源、市场营销、自媒体运营、财务税务、投资融资、成长管理和安全退出等全方位支持。更有扎根于社区、广受欢迎的每月一期的国际企业家实战研习营。 蜂巢聚创已受到中外媒体的广泛关注与报道。曾被新华社称赞为"最接地气的创业营”，是联邦、紐约州和紐約市小商业发展局认可并扶持的社区创业服务专业机构。 蜂巢聚创热忱欢迎你！这是一个最靠谱的创业研习营立足纽约，放眼中美

results.description:
In Kundalini Yoga we harness the mental, physical, and nervous energies of the body and put them under the domain of the will, which is the instrument of the soul. This technology precisely and consciously combines breath, mudra, eye-focus, mantra, body locks, and postures to balance the glandular system, strengthen the nervous system, expand lung capacity, and purify the blood. It brings balance to the body, mind, and soul.

"In Kundalini Yoga the most important thing is your experience. It goes right to your heart. No words can replace your experience. Your mind may accept the words or it may not, but your consciousness will not accept just words."  
-Yogi Bhajan, The Aquarian Teacher Training manual, p. 20


All levels - beginner to intermediate are welcome.

Fee: $20 Single class drop in, $75 for 5 class pack, $150- 10 class pack.


Please come in 15 minutes earlier so we can all be signed up and ready to start. You can also sign up on-line to make it easier: https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/ASP/home.asp?studioid=299

**Bring a Yoga Mat, Blanket and Bottle of Water to class. Wear loose comfortable clothing made with natural fibers.

results.description:
HackNewark is an all day hackathon where techies and new-comers will dedicate a full day to building prototypes aimed at addressing real dilemmas in our community.

What is a Hackathon?

A hackathon is a digital workshop in which computer programmers, graphic designers, interface designers, project managers, community activists, artists and newbs (other interested members of the community) to collaborate intensively on solving problems.

What is HackNewark?

Is a type of hackathon focused on a specific data sets. The outcome produces visualizations, analytics and apps based on this data; for Newark!

#HACKNEWARK

View Schedule and agenda here: https://hacknewark.com/

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Updated December 18th, 2015


WINTER (Dec-Feb)

As the city gets cold we play two times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd & West End) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd & West End)

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

Damien 


[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

[img src="">

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

results.description:
S3 FPV Racing - Gates, Flags and Fun ! Public Event, CHYZOWYCH FIELD across the tracks from Columbia HIgh School.  Google Map to get a sense of where you are going.


This is a special race event celebrating the FAA Drone regulations!

 Drones weighing less than 250g do not have to be registered.  Bring your 'off the radar' sub 250g, FPV Ready drones and race on our conventional FPV race course!

If it weighs less than 250 grams, bring it and race it! No other restrictions apply! (except for 200mW VTX)

Remember - Weigh it before you come out.  Nothing over 250 grams will be allowed.

Pilots and associated drone weights will be announced via bullhorn ala Boxing Match style!  Weigh ins are mandatory!

Internally Safety Third is competing for the optimal sub 250g racing drone and will be racing.  Click below for details:

LINK TDB

We will be configuring a MultiGP Time Trial course for both racing and time recording.


If you do not have a Multi GP Pilot record yet, please create one and join our chapter :
http://www.multigp.com/chapters/view/Safety-Third-Racing-Team

Race events will be posted to multiGP later.  Secure your spot by RSVP Yes to this meetup.

Unofficial Team S3 time UTT1 top speed:


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zrILYcovINI

Arrival Time: 10:30 AM, Free fly begins 11AM

 
Cost to fly None 


Note: As there is no power onsite, you'll need to bring enough charged batteries to race the entire day or invest in field charging gear. Ask some S3 Team Members for equipment advice. This is an open field - bring at least a chair. More info below.

Check-in: When you arrive, please check in with the Event Captain (typically Frank or Will) for safety, frequency allocations and course updates. 

 
Agenda: 


· Sign in/Registration/Pre-Free-Fly
· Free Fly Pilot Briefing/Walk the course
· Free Fly/Course Practice
· Racing Pilot Briefing
· Heat Assignments
· Racing (Time Trials, 3S, 4S, Speed, Win and Out, Finals)
· Streamer Chase

 ________________________________________________
First Timers: If this is your first time joining us, Welcome! Please take a few moments and read the notes below on our best practices for piloting, frequency and safety management. PLEASE CHECK IN WITH THE FLIGHT/SAFETY COORDINATOR before you fly or power up anything. First timers will be paired with an established S3 Team Pilot as your “Event Buddy”. You can observe firsthand S3 team pilots doing the following: flight preparation, pit adjustments, frequency compliance, field behavior and group signaling/announcing.
Got a non-racing, photography multirotor? It's always an awesome sight to see a large frame in the air capturing hi-res photography, so if you have one, please bring it. Please check in with Frank to make sure all video transmission is disabled. You will have to fly this line-of-site or run a 200mW VTX and adhere to frequency management to not interfere with the FPV racers.
Not flying? There's lot's of technical expertise, lurkers, newbies, and interested friends just hanging out, so even if you don't race, you can still fly, take videos, or just watch and learn. 

Please check in at the line of canopies at the end of the parking area and ask for Frank. 


  Suggested equipment to bring:
Your aircraft(s), props and batteries, repair equipment
Something to sit on – this is an open field.
Something to sit under like a small (or large) canopy. Team members do bring canopies to manage their equipment and make repairs. We ask that everyone respects the space they need to operate comfortable.
AMA License: If you plan on flying, you can get it here: http://www.modelaircraft.org/).
Safety glasses or high impact sunglasses (for young pilots under 13 it is HIGHLY recommended)
Sunscreen and water. 

GENERAL HOUSEKEEPING:
NO FLY ZONE: For safety, the no fly zone is "IN, ABOVE AND BEHIND" the line formed by the pilot pit area. You may not operate your quad behind or to the right of the last canopy. When coming in for a landing, please approach slowly and don't prop wash/buzz everyone, there are lots of pilots "blind" with FPV goggles that can't tell if you are out of control or not. 


FLY ZONE: All pilots and spectators should stay out of the fly zone . Please pilot your aircraft from within the pit area (aka the no-fly-zone). If you crash or need to enter the field, please wait until races are over, and call out in the pit area your intentions so other pilots can avoid you. During free flight/ practice. you may enter the field by announcing “ON THE FIELD” loudly to entire pit area. 


CRASH & TRASH: Take out what you brought in, including a little extra while you're at it. That way we're always spotless and keep the park rangers happy. 

 
KIDS: we encourage bringing any family members and kids interested in RC flying, as it's a great place for young pilots to learn best practices in the art of FPV. For ground/flight safety purposes, we ask that all young pilots be always supervised and mentored on safe flying practices, kept away from dangerous fly zones, and be courteous/don't touch without asking in all staging areas. It is highly recommended for kids to wear protective eyewear. 

 
"ZERO HARM" RESPONSIBLE FLYING: Our group prides itself on minimal rules and attracts folks that are mindful, safety conscious oriented and considerate of other pilots, bystanders, pets, wildlife and the environment. IOW, if you are about to have a collision, especially with a dog, bird, human, or any living thing, think "zero harm" first and do everything you can to avoid the collision and immediately divert your flight path even if it means at the expense of your own rig. Living things are a lot harder to repair than metal and electronics and typically don't require litigation to fix. If in doubt please ask about best practices from any of the experienced pilots, we're all here to help learn and have a really great time together. 

 
RACING: Know your skill limits and pilot your quad accordingly. When flying, please be aware of other pilots calling out in the pit. Typically these are "Person on the course, dog on the course chasing rig, powering up on Vtx channel "X" , or the most critical, "WHOMEVER JUST POWERED UP, PLEASE POWER DOWN IMMEDIATELY!" and so on. It is critical you do not fly over people in the pit or other visitors in the park. But beyond this, most importantly, have a blast of fun! 

 
FREQUENCY MANAGEMENT
Since most pilots are using the 5.8ghz video transmitter bands for FPV video, so please be aware of your transmitter type (Fatshark/Immersion or Boscam) and frequency channel. Every pilot uses this technology to fly their aircraft safely, so it is imperative that every pilot understands and operates using safe video transmission practices. 

 
THE BASICS:
1) Never power up your video TRANSMITTER without first checking that there is no one else currently transmitting on the same channel. LOOK THROUGH YOU GOGGLES FIRST. Someone may accidentally be on the channel you were assigned. Listen intently when you do (even if you have a frequency tag), and if you hear a pilot exclaim that they've lost signal, power down immediately. Flying blind is a dangerous situation and is to be avoided at all costs.
2) Power up your video RECEIVER and goggles/display first BEFORE you power up your aircraft and video transmitter. If you see someone else's signal, then you need to switch your channel, you're stomping.
3) During races, only those in the race should be transmitting video .
4) For racing, the racing coordinator(s) will make frequency assignments and assign spotters.
5) Please arrange the video transmitter on your aircraft so that the dip switches/button to change your channels are easily accessible. You may need to change channels quickly just before your scheduled heat. 

 
Looking forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
Nitrox is a breathing gas that has a lot of benefits for both new and experienced divers. This course will cover the use of nitrox mixtures from 22 to 40 percent oxygen.

EZ Nitrox was developed to introduce even the newest of divers to NITROX Diving

Enroll now to get started with on-line academics which need to be completed before this session. 
Come to the Dive Center and we will review the academics and do the practical application session. Here you will get hands-on experience on how to

Analyze: You need to know how to analyze to ensure the proper and safest FO2 for your dive.

Label: Know what to and how to properly mark on your cylinder.

Log: Fill out the blenders log to ensure you get the percentages you asked for.

+: Program a dive computer for Nitrox

Working with an Oxygen analyzer and Dive computer will prepare you to maximize the benefits of Nitrox diving to meet your diving needs.

Pr-registration is required. For more info call[masked]

The SDI OnLine Computer Nitrox course is a great next step after 
the Open Water Diver certification and is structured in an easy to understand manner by making use of a Nitrox programmable computer. Nitrox as a breathing gas has a lot of benefits for both new and experienced. The course will cover the use of Nitrox mixtures from 22 to 40 percent oxygen.

The benefits of using Nitrox include 
* Increased safety margins 
* Reduced post dive fatigue 
* Extended no-decompression times

When you have completed the academic review and practical application sessions, we will will process your permanent certification card. What could be easier? Nitrox opens a world of possibilities, leading to better, more enjoyable diving. What are you waiting for?

Pre-registration required.  Includes the eLearning codes and the practical session. Cost $148 ea. Pay online Now! and we will wave the registration  (A $34.00 value)

C-Card processing and registration is $34

Refresher $29.95 (proof of cert required)

Pay now and I'll email you the access code to start the online academics

Optional Openwater dives can be conducted at Dutch Springs or on one of our Dive Trips

The greatest benefits of Nitrox are found between 0 and 130 feet, and require just a little more training and experience. Nitrox is another tool for divers to use. It is not designed to replace air. Nitrox is ideal for recreational diving. You can gain a safety advantage OR longer bottom times using Nitrox. In either case, many divers report less fatigue and a sense of well-being after Nitrox dives. 
In addition to feeling better after diving, the decrease of of nitrogen accumulation also allows:

Increased safety margins when using dive computers.

A significant increase in bottom time no-decompression limits when using Nitrox tables.

A reduction of decompression time if the no-decompression limits are exceeded.

A reduction of possible decompression illness.

Reduces the effects of Nitrogen Narcosis.


What is Nitrox? 
Nitrox is simply any mixture of oxygen and nitrogen. Air is made up of 21% oxygen and 79% nitrogen. The name "Nitrox" usually refers to oxygen-nitrogen mixtures containing more than 21% oxygen. Other names for this gas are EANx, Enriched Air Nitrox and Safe Air. There are two standard Nitrox mixtures. Nitrox containing 32% oxygen and Nitrox containing 36% oxygen.

Why should I use Nitrox? 
The main benefit to diving with Nitrox is the reduced amount of nitrogen in your breathing gas. Less nitrogen means less risk of getting decompression sickness (DCS), or "the bends". Using Nitrox can also extend your bottom time. Because no-decompression limits are based on nitrogen absorption, less nitrogen means more bottom time. Many divers also claim that they feel less fatigued after diving with Nitrox (as compared to diving with air).

Why do I need a Nitrox Course? 
Nitrox, like all other breathing gases (including air), has its safe limits at depth so it is very important to know and understand these limits before you make your first Nitrox dive. You will also need a Nitrox Certification card to purchase mixed gases. To fully understand the benefits of using Nitrox it is important to receive proper training. Classroom sessions include information on the theory of diving Nitrox, blending, dive tables, gas analyzing and dive planning. Upon completion you will receive your certification allowing you to use Nitrox for all your diving adventures.

In addition to feeling better after diving, the decrease of of nitrogen accumulation also allows: 
- Increased safety margins when using computers. 
- A significant increase in bottom time no-decompression limits when using Dive Computer Nitrox plan. 
- A reduction of possible decompression illness. 
- A reduction of decompression time if the no-decompression limits are exceeded. 
- Reduces the effects of Nitrogen Narcosis.

Nitrox Equipment 
Most of your regular scuba equipment will work without modification for use with Nitrox. Your regulator, pressure hoses and other equipment will work just fine.

results.description:
Please read the full description . . .

Your first question will undoubtedly be, what is Holi Phagwah? Holi and Phagwah kinda refer to the same thing. 

Holi is "a spring festival, also known as the festival of colours or the festival of Sharing love. It is an ancient Hindu religious festival which has become popular with non-Hindus in many parts of South Asia, as well as people of other communities outside Asia. It is primarily observed in India, Nepal, and other regions of the world with significant populations of Hindus or people of Indian origin. In recent years the festival has spread to parts of Europe and North America as a spring celebration of love, frolic, and colours."

Phagwah refers to the Guyanese version of Holi. The area of Richmond Hill where the parade is held is often called "Little Guyana." More about Phagwah below.

You will be covered in colors by the end of this and you will have a tremendous amount of fun doing so.

We will meet outside the Queens Library on Lefferts, near the parade route. It may be crowded, so we will need to get there early. Once we're gathered, we will go purchase our colored powder and then stake out a spot along Liberty Avenue. After the parade (starts roughly 12pm), we will proceed to Phil Rizzuto Park (Smokey Oval Park).

• Wear something you don't mind getting dirty, stained. Though the colors do not typically stain, there are no guarantees. 

• Wear light colored or even white clothes to show off the colors. It will make for some great photos and you'll want to get in the spirit of it (trust me;) 

• Bring cash to buy some colors 

• Most of all, bring your good vibes and prepare to have a joyous time. A handful of us went a couple years back and had a blast. Words cannot suffice, so here's some pics . . .

More details about the parade and Phagwah below . . . 

"The parade is scheduled to be held March 26 at 12 p.m., beginning at 133rd Street and Liberty Avenue, and ending at Phil “Scooter” Rizzuto Park at 125th Street and Atlantic Avenue, where hundreds will throw colorful powder to celebrate the rites of spring."

http://www.timesledger.com/stories/2016/8/phagwah_2016_02_19_q.html 

http://www.phagwahparade.us/hpfcphagwah-parade.html 

"Phagwah is one of the most ancient, joyous and colorful festivals of the Hindu calendar. This festival was brought down from Indian in 1838, by Indian Indentured Immigrants. 
Holi is celebrated forty days from the planting of Holika (Castor Oil tree). The burning of Holika takes place on the Eve of Phagwah (full moon night). A huge structure (pyre) is built and kindled at the appropriate time in a symbolic act. Phagwah commemorates the New Year for Hindus. 
Phagwah started at a time when India was facing a serious drought, affecting the various crops. However, the rain eventually came pouring down to the satisfaction of the people (farmers) who came out in the fields; playing with the water in joyous jubilation as they throw it on each other. Soon after, they start reaping their bountiful harvest (crop). 
There are special forms of music and songs which are associated with Phagwah; Chowtaal singing is the dominant style, which is heard from Basant Panchmi night until eight days after Phagwah. 
Holi was celebrated before the Prahalad’s legend. However, the story of Prahalad added new dimensions. Prahalad’s defiance of the many impositions of his father, King Hiranyakasyapu is testimony and evidence of firm faith in Truth and God. The burning of Holika (Prahalad’s Aunt) is reminiscent of his victory over evil. King Kasyapu contrived various diabolical means to kill his son Prahalad, who went against his will, but all his efforts were in vein. King Hiranyakasyapu; has a blessing (boon) that he would not die in the day or night, nor inside or outside of his house nor would he be killed by man or beast. So he felt that he was God and proclaimed that all worship must be henceforth Given to him. 
Soon after, Lord Vishnu came in the awful form of Narsingh (half man and half lion) at twilight (neither day nor night). Lord Vishnu brought to an end the tyranny, arrogance and atrocity of the evil King (Hiranyakasyapu) in the centre of the doorway (neither inside nor outside of the house). 
Holi in all embracing has a historic meaning with a strong social content which caters for reunion, social exchanges, greetings and visits, it also provides for spiritual communion and economic assessment so that the New Year can experience the emergency of a world free from want, poverty, full of justice and goodwill. 
`When the winter is over and nature rejoices, it is time for us to bring out the abeer, abrack, powder, perfume, beat the drums, sound the jhaal, sing and dancing for it is harvest time. The spring crop is reaped and everyone is in a happy mood, bubbling with enthusiasm and in joyous jubilation as they celebrate. 
The coloured water/powder symbolized the unique floral beauty of spring and the vanishing of hatred feelings, jealousy and enmity, and bringing into the community a feeling of togetherness. This celebration sees all cast and class as one. The red does not represent anyone’s blood."

http://www.kaieteurnewsonline.com/2012/03/08/the-significance-of-phagwah-2/ 

“A HAPPY AND JOYOUS PHAGWAH TO ALL”

results.name: Holi Phagwah Parade and Celebration

results.description:
We return to the topic of Renormalization in Quantum Field theories by considering the four point function.  We will see the effects of integrating the short distance degrees of freedom of this theory and how Wilson devised and ingenious method of handling the various kinds of divergences which crop up.

Amol will start by recapping his presentation of last time, touching on dimensional regularization and the treatment of high  momentum cut-offs.

Good reading....Chapter 9.1 of Peskin and Schroeder, and chapter 12 of the same. I found this paper good too.

http://www.physics.mcgill.ca/~jcline/qft1b.pdf

There are many good sources on the internet that provide an introduction to the Renormalization Group.

This is a topic that always stifled me in self-studying QFT, and I suspect that I am not alone. 

Please join us for what promises to be an accessible treatment of this all important topic in particle physics (and statistical mechanics)
results.name: Renormalization Group Flow in Phi 4 Theory

results.description:
It's not quite spring yet, but with these warm temperatures we're trying an outdoor sketch a little earlier this year. Keep your fingers crossed.

Brooklyn Bridge Park keeps growing and improving, and it's changed a lot since we sketched it last. One cool thing there now is an art exhibit with 18 sculptures scattered throughout the park. Details here.

We'll meet at the east end of the park, on the corner of Main St and Plymouth St. It's near the F stop. Then we'll sketch the carousel and walk west through the park, sketching the scenery and sculptures and ending up at the new piers.

Any problems on the day of the event, I can be reached at [masked]. 


Looking forward to sketching with you!


----------

In case of rain, I will let people know early in the morning if it is canceled, and then reschedule for another day.

----------

What makes our Meetups different from other art groups and classes? There's no instruction, but we like to share our work, and chat and be inspired. Share tips and learn from people in a casual environment where all levels of artists are welcome! Don't be shy to ask anyone anything!

• We sketch for a bit, usually 45 minutes or so, and then get back together and share our drawings, and then sketch again, etc. There's usually time for 3 or 4 sketches.

• Please bring your own supplies - anything you like to work with - pens, pencil, watercolor, pastel, small sketchbook or large paper, iPad, whatever suits you.

• We hand out nametags so everyone can meet one another!

• We take photos to share on the site later. Take a bunch!

• Please take care to make sure we do not leave any trash behind. Please also leave the dogs at home; they tend to knock over the artwork. Thanks. 

• This Meetup is FREE and everyone at all skill levels is welcome!

----------

How does the Wait List work? If the event is full, rsvp to be added to the Wait List. If someone from the regular list cancels, the first person on the Wait List is automatically bumped up to regular attendee.

Please note that if you add a comment below it will spam everyone with an email, so please use your judgement.
results.name: Draw Brooklyn Bridge Park!

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
